issue.title: hash should be std qualified for unordered container

discussion.p: Tom Plum pointed out to me that there's an apparent inconsistency in the std:: qualification of template names in the unordered containers:
Is there a reason that hash is not qualified with std::? TR1 also does not use std:: here.
I assumed (I might be wrong) it is because hash is designed to be a customisation point, like swap.

I think this is incorrect. We mean std::hash, though clients are free to specialize std::hash on user-defined types. With the possible exception of begin/end (which I'm not sure if we've settled that), swap is the only intended customization point (look up a function by ADL) in the std:: lib.
I recommend NAD, due to p3:

blockquote.p: Whenever a name x defined in the standard library is mentioned, the name x is assumed to be fully qualified as ::std::x, unless explicitly described otherwise. For example, if the Effects section for library function F is described as calling library function G, the function ::std::G is meant.
